questions.text: Painful multiple lesions on foot of a farmer with various draining sinuses as shown in the image. Choose the correct etiological agent?

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1 -The H.nana eggs are roughly spherical/ovoid. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore that encloses the hexacanth oncosphere. - The eggs of Ancyclostoma duodenale has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane. It contains a segmented ovum, usually with 4-8 blastomeres. There is a clear space between the ovum and the shell. -The eggs of Taenia Solium and Taenia saginata are indistinguishable. The inner embryophore is radially striated . A fully developed (oncosphere) with three pairs of hooklets (hexacanth embryo) is present in the centre. - Ascaris Lumbricoides have a thick translucent shell with : •An outer coarsely mammillated albuminous coat • A thick transparent middle layer •An inner lipoidal vitteline membrane .

questions.text: H/o trauma six weeks ago. Lymphatic spread of the lesion has shown in the image. All the organisms have the property of lymphatic spread except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Corynebacterium minutissimum. The image shows a series of red, raised lesions following the path of lymphatic vessels, a pattern known as sporotrichoid spread This type of spread is characteristic of infections that enter the skin through a break and then travel along the lymphatics. Analysis of the Options A. Sporothrix: This refers to Sporothrix schenckii, the fungus that causes sporotrichosis (or "rose gardener's disease"). It is the classic example of an organism that causes a sporotrichoid pattern of lymphatic spread, often following a thorn prick or similar trauma. B. Nocardia brasiliensis: This bacterium can cause nocardiosis. In its cutaneous form, it commonly presents with a sporotrichoid pattern, with an initial lesion followed by secondary nodules along the draining lymphatics. D. Mycobacterium marinum: This bacterium can cause an atypical mycobacterial infection, often from exposure to contaminated water (e.g., aquariums). It frequently presents as a single lesion but can also spread along lymphatic channels, mimicking the sporotrichoid pattern. C. Corynebacterium minutissimum: This bacterium is the causative agent of erythrasma, a superficial skin infection. Erythrasma typically presents as a well-demarcated, reddish-brown patch in skin folds (like the groin or armpit). It does not have the property of causing deep lesions or spreading along lymphatic vessels. Therefore, it

questions.text: The cell wall shown below belongs to which organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Neisseria meningitidis Neisseria meningitidis, often referred to as meningococcus, is a Gram negative bacterium that can cause meningitis and other forms of meningococcal disease such as meningococcemia, a life-threatening sepsis. Lipooligosaccharide is present in the outer membrane of Neisseria. It acts like an endotoxin and is responsible for septic shock. Other virulence features are polysaccharide capsule, that prevents its phagocytosis and aids evasion by host immune system. Adhesion is another key virulence feature to successfully invade host cell. There are many such proteins, including Pili which mediate attachment of the bacteria to the epithelial lining of the nasopharynx.

questions.text: Gram positive bacilli isolated from a child, that is motile at 22 degrees and non-motile at 37 degrees is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Listeria monocytogenes Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram positive bacterium, and a facultative anaerobic bacterium, capable of surviving in the presence or absence of oxygen. It exhibits differential motility, that is, it grows at 22 degrees and not at 37 degrees. It exhibits a tumbling type of motility. Its ability to grow at temperatures as low as 0 °C permits multiplication at typical refrigeration temperatures, greatly increasing its ability to evade control in human foodstuffs. It can cause meningitis in neonates, cancer and transplant patients. It can also produce Granulomatum infantiseptica.

questions.text: Which haematological manifestation associated with this image ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pure red cell aplasia The given image shows “Slapped cheek appearance” seen in Erythema infectiosum. This is caused by Parvovirus B19, which is a non-enveloped ss DNA virus. Other associations of Parvovirus are Non-immune fetal hydrops, polyarthritis in adults, blueberry muffin rash and Pure red cell aplasia causing aplastic crisis.

questions.text: Infective form of toxoplasmosis to humans from cat feces is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Oocyst Toxoplasma gondii is a protozoan parasite that infects most species of warm-blooded animals, including humans, and causes the disease toxoplasmosis. The only known definitive hosts for Toxoplasma gondii are members of family Felidae (domestic cats and their relatives). Humans can become infected by any of several routes: • Eating undercooked meat of animals harboring tissue cysts . • Consuming food or water contaminated with cat feces or by contaminated environmental samples (such as fecal-contaminated soil or changing the litter box of a pet cat) . • Blood transfusion or organ transplantation . • Transplacentally from mother to fetus .

questions.text: Protozoan pathogen found in Kupffer cells is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Leishmania Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoa of genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by the bite of female Phlebotomus sandfly. The lifecycle of Leishmania includes two forms: Promastigote (in sandfly vector) and Amastigote (in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host). The amastigote form is also known as Leishmania-Donovan (LD) body. It is an intracellular form inside the macrophages. Kupffer cells are the macrophages of the liver. Plasmodium and Babesia are present in RBCs. Giardia is a free protozoa, not intracellular.

questions.text: Choose the correct incubation periods
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A-2, B-3, C-4 D-1 Incubation period of Hepatitis viruses: Hepatitis A- 15-45 days Hepatitis B- 30-180 days Hepatitis C- 15-160 days Incubation period of commonly sexually transmitted infections: Syphilis- 10-90 days Chancroid- 2-5 days Donovanosis- 8-80 days Gonorrhea- 2-30 days

questions.text: Identify the pathogen:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Aspergillus The hyphae of the fungus in the given diagram are septate and have acute angle branching. That is suggestive of Aspergillus. Mucor have aseptate hyphae with obtuse angle branching. Aspergillus can cause a variety of infections in the human body such as- • Acute invasive aspergillosis, a form that grows into surrounding tissue, more common in those with weakened immune systems such as AIDS or chemotherapy patients • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, which affects patients with respiratory diseases such as asthma, cystic fibrosis, and sinusitis • Aspergilloma, a "fungus ball" that can form within cavities such as the lung • Disseminated invasive aspergillosis, an infection spread widely through the body

questions.text: A woman from Tamil Nadu presents with a mass protruding from her nose. What is the pathogen implicated in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rhinosporidium seeberi Rhinosporidiosis is an infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous disease affecting the mucous membrane of nasopharynx, oropharynx, conjunctiva, rectum and external genitalia. Though the floor of the nose and inferior turbinate are the most common sites, the lesions may appear elsewhere too. Traumatic inoculation from one site to others is common. On histopathology, thick walled sporangia with 1000+ endospores, each 6 - 10 microns, accompanied by a mixed inflammatory infiltrate is seen. Treatment is by surgical excision.

questions.text: A diabetic patient with immunocompromised state presents with a fungal infection. On biopsy, budding cells with pseudohyphae were present. What is the condition indicated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Invasive candidiasis Invasive candidiasis is an infection that can be caused by various species of Candida yeast. Many species of Candida are harmless commensals or endosymbionts of hosts including humans; however, when mucosal barriers are disrupted or the immune system is compromised they can invade and cause disease, known as an opportunistic infection. The diagram given below shows the budding yeast cells of Candida.

questions.text: Serial dilutions of agglutination test is given here. Negative till 1:40 dilution is due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Excess antibody The reason for positive sample on serial dilutions is called Prozone phenomenon and it occurs to due to excess antibodies as compared with the antigens. On further dilution, there is equal number of Ab and Ag, which produce a lattice and is visible as positive. However on diluting further, Antigens will outnumber the antigens, called Postzone phenomenon. Pro and Postzone phenomenon are false negative.

questions.text: A patient presents with bloody dysentery. Imaging reveals a liver abscess in the right lobe of the liver with irregular margins. What is the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Amoebic liver abscess A amoebic liver abscess is a type of liver abscess caused by amebiasis. It is the involvement of liver tissue by trophozoites of the organism Entamoeba histolytica. Approximately 90% of patients with E histolytica are asymptomatic. The two most common manifestations of E histolytica include colitis (bloody stool with mucus, abdominal pain, and/or diarrhea), and discovery of a liver abscess on imaging. Liver abscess commonly present as right upper quadrant abdominal pain and fever, with worsening features associated with abscess rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following is not transmitted perinatally?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rubella Rubella is an acute, contagious viral infection. While rubella virus infection usually causes a mild fever and rash in children and adults, infection during pregnancy, especially during the first trimester, can result in miscarriage, fetal death, stillbirth, or infants with congenital malformations, known as congenital rubella syndrome (CRS). If infection occurs 0–11 weeks after conception, the infant has a 90% risk of being affected. If the infection occurs 12–20 weeks after conception, the risk is 20%. Infants are not generally affected if rubella is contracted during the third trimester. The classic triad for congenital rubella syndrome is: • Sensorineural deafness • Eye abnormalities—especially retinopathy, cataract, glaucoma and microphthalmia. • Congenital heart disease—especially pulmonary artery stenosis and patent ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: PCR which of the organism needed a step of reverse transcriptase
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a technique that amplifies DNA. However, many viruses, like Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV), have a genome made of RNA rather than DNA. To detect these viruses using PCR, their RNA genome must first be converted into DNA. This conversion is performed by an enzyme called reverse transcriptase in a process known as reverse transcription. The resulting complementary DNA (cDNA) can then be amplified by standard PCR. This combined technique is known as reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR).

questions.text: Cell to cell transfer of bacteria by actin filament is classically seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answe-(C)

questions.text: Which toxin acts by the MoA shown in the image.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The image shows the mechanism of action of diphtheria toxin, which is produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is an A-B exotoxin where the B subunit binds to the host cell membrane and facilitates entry of the A subunit. Once inside the cell, the A subunit catalyzes ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2) using NAD?. This modification inactivates EF-2, which is essential for protein synthesis at the ribosome. As a result, the cell is unable to synthesize proteins, leading to cell death. This classic mechanism is highly characteristic of diphtheria toxin and explains its cytotoxic effects. Incorrect Option: A. Vibrio cholerae Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin, which is also an A-B exotoxin but works through a different mechanism. It ADP-ribosylates the Gs alpha subunit, leading to persistent activation of adenylate cyclase. This increases intracellular cAMP levels, causing chloride and water secretion into the intestinal lumen and resulting in profuse watery diarrhea. It does not inhibit EF-2 or interfere with protein synthesis. Incorrect Option: B. Bacillus anthracis Bacillus anthracis produces anthrax toxin, which consists of three components: protective antigen, edema factor, and lethal factor. Edema factor acts as an adenylate cyclase, increasing cAMP levels, while lethal factor is a protease that inactivates MAP kinase signaling pathways. These effects lead to immune evasion, edema, and cell death but not via inhibition of EF-2 or protein synthesis machinery. Incorrect Option: D. Clostridium perfringens Clostridium perfringens primarily produces alpha toxin, which is a lecithinase (phospholipase C). This toxin causes cell membrane disruption by degrading phospholipids, leading to cell lysis and tissue necrosis, especially seen in gas gangrene. It does not target EF-2 or affect protein synthesis, so it is not the correct match for the image shown.

questions.text: Which organism needs BSL 3
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) XDR TB. BSL-3 Organisms Biosafety Level 3 (BSL-3) is required for work involving indigenous or exotic microbes that can cause serious or potentially lethal disease through aerosol transmission (inhalation). All work with these microbes must be performed in a biosafety cabinet. XDR TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) is caused by a strain of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an airborne pathogen that causes a serious, potentially lethal disease and is classified as a Risk Group 3 agent. This makes it a prime example of an organism requiring a BSL-3 laboratory.

questions.text: A person living in a rural area comes to you with complaints of neck rigidity and fever. Hemiparesis present. Clinically diagnosed as encephalitis. H/o Swimming present. SEM image shown here. Choose the correct Pathogen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Naegleria fowleri. The clinical presentation of a person with neck rigidity, fever, and hemiparesis is consistent with a diagnosis of encephalitis. The crucial clue is the history of swimming, which is the primary route of infection for Naegleria fowleri, the causative agent of a severe condition called Primary Amebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM). This amoeba is found in warm fresh water, and when it enters the nasal passages, it can travel to the brain. The provided SEM image is a classic depiction of the trophozoite stage of Naegleria fowleri, characterized by its distinctive eruptive pseudopods. The other options are less likely; Acanthamoeba and Balamuthia mandrillaris typically cause a slower, chronic form of encephalitis in immunocompromised individuals, and Giardia lamblia is a gastrointestinal parasite.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is essential for permeating of viral RNA of HIV through membrane of host cell?
questions.solution: Correct Answer-(A) For HIV's viral RNA to enter a host cell, the viral envelope must fuse with the host cell membrane. The GP41 (Glycoprotein 41) is the crucial viral transmembrane glycoprotein that directly mediates this membrane fusion event. After the initial binding steps (GP120 binding to CD4 and a co-receptor), GP41 undergoes a conformational change that drives the fusion of the viral and host cell membranes, effectively creating a pore through which the viral contents, including the RNA, can pass into the host cell cytoplasm. Incorrect Options: Option (B. GP120) Explanation: GP120 (Glycoprotein 120) is the surface glycoprotein of the HIV envelope. Its primary function is binding to the host cell's CD4 receptor and subsequently to a co-receptor (like CCR5 or CXCR4). While essential for the overall entry process by initiating attachment, GP120 itself does not directly mediate the fusion of the viral and host cell membranes or the permeation of the RNA. Option (C. CXCR5) Explanation: CXCR5 (C-X-C chemokine receptor type 5) is a host cell surface protein, not a viral structure. More importantly, while chemokine receptors are crucial co-receptors for HIV entry, CXCR5 is not one of the primary co-receptors (which are CCR5 and CXCR4) utilized by HIV for infection. Option (D. CCR4) Explanation: CCR4 (C-C chemokine receptor type 4) is also a host cell surface protein, not a viral structure. Similar to CXCR5, CCR4 is not a primary co-receptor used by HIV for entry. The main host co-receptors are CCR5 and CXCR4.

questions.text: What are the advantages of saline wet mount over iodine wet mount? A. Motility can be studied better B. To stain nucleus and glycogen mass C. Bile-stained egg can be differentiated D. Cyst can be specifically identified by this method
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A. Motility can be studied better Saline wet mount allows for the observation of motility in living organisms, such as protozoa (e.g., Giardia, Trichomonas). Because saline does not kill or alter the organisms, it allows them to remain alive, and their motility can be studied clearly. This is a distinct advantage over iodine wet mount, which tends to kill or immobilize the organisms due to its staining properties. C. Bile-stained egg can be differentiated Saline wet mount helps to differentiate bile-stained eggs in parasitic infections. The bile-stained eggs (e.g., from Ascaris lumbricoides or Clonorchis sinensis) are transparent, and in saline, they are easier to identify due to their natural appearance and the way the eggs react in a saline solution. Iodine may stain these eggs, making them harder to differentiate in certain cases, especially if the bile staining is subtle. Saline allows for a clearer, unstained view, which can be particularly helpful in bile-stained egg identification. Incorrect Answers: B. To stain nucleus and glycogen mass Iodine wet mount is specifically used for staining nuclei and glycogen masses, particularly in protozoa. The iodine solution stains these structures, making them more visible and easier to identify. Saline wet mount does not have this staining property and is used for observing live motile organisms or identifying cysts in their natural state, without staining. D. Cyst can be specifically identified by this method While saline wet mount can help in identifying the shape of cysts, iodine wet mount is typically preferred for highlighting and staining cyst walls and internal contents (e.g., glycogen masses and nuclei). The iodine stain makes these features stand out clearly, whereas saline allows the cyst to be seen but does not enhance the visualization of internal structures.

questions.text: An Immunocompromised individual came with white patches in tongue which cannot be rubbed. Etiological agent is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In an immunocompromised individual, such as someone with HIV/AIDS, the appearance of white patches on the tongue that cannot be rubbed off is a classic sign of oral hairy leukoplakia. This condition is painless, typically appears along the sides (lateral borders) of the tongue, and is not removable by scraping. The cause of this condition is the Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV), which becomes reactivated in immunosuppressed individuals. Unlike oral candidiasis (thrush), which is caused by Candida albicans and presents with removable white plaques, oral hairy leukoplakia is firmly attached to the mucosa due to thickening of the epithelium with viral involvement. It's important to distinguish this condition clinically because it often signals underlying immune deficiency, particularly HIV infection. Other options, such as HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus) or KSHV (Kaposi Sarcoma virus), present with painful ulcers or tumors, not white plaques that can't be scraped off. Therefore, EBV is the correct etiological agent.

questions.text: Dengue warning sign
questions.solution: Correct Answer-(B) These are features that suggest the patient may progress to severe dengue, and hospitalization is recommended. Dengue Warning Signs include: Persistent vomiting Abdominal pain or tenderness Mucosal bleeding Clinical fluid accumulation (ascites, pleural effusion) Lethargy or restlessness Liver enlargement >2 cm Sudden increase in hematocrit with rapid drop in platelet count

questions.text: Which one of the following shows drug resistance?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A. Donovanosis: Also known as granuloma inguinale, this sexually transmitted infection is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It is typically responsive to antibiotics such as azithromycin, doxycycline, erythromycin, ciprofloxacin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. While prolonged therapy is often required, significant drug resistance has not been widely reported. ? B. Syphilis: Caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum, syphilis remains highly sensitive to penicillin. Penicillin G is the treatment of choice, and there have been no significant reports of resistance to this antibiotic. ? C. Gonorrhoea: Caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, this infection has developed resistance to multiple antibiotics over time, including penicillins, sulphonamides, tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones, and macrolides. The emergence of strains resistant to cephalosporins, particularly ceftriaxone, poses a significant public health challenge, as treatment options become increasingly limited. ? D. Chlamydia: Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, this infection is generally treated with antibiotics like azithromycin or doxycycline. While treatment failures can occur, widespread antibiotic resistance has not been a significant concern to date. ?

questions.text: How to disinfect disposable mouth piece of glass pipette A. Autoclave B. Hot air oven C. Ethanol 70% D.Microwave
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A, B are Correct A. Autoclave: This is the most effective method for sterilizing glass pipettes. Autoclaving uses high pressure and temperature (typically 121°C) to kill all microorganisms, including resistant spores. Glass is heat-resistant and can easily withstand the autoclaving process, making it ideal for sterilization. B. Hot air oven: This is also a valid method for sterilizing glass pipettes. It uses dry heat, typically at 160°C to 180°C, to sterilize glass. This method is effective but generally takes longer than autoclaving. C. Ethanol 70%: Ethanol can be used for disinfection, but it doesn't achieve sterilization. While it can reduce the microbial load on the glass surface, it doesn't kill all forms of bacteria or viruses, especially more resistant organisms like spores. D. Microwave: This is not a suitable method for sterilizing glass pipettes. Microwaving could lead to uneven heating and may not be effective in killing microorganisms. Glass pipettes may also get damaged in the microwave.

questions.text: The following one is antibiotic sensitivity testing.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) E test An E test, or Epsilometer test, is a method used in microbiology to determine the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of an antibiotic. A strip with a gradient of antibiotic concentration is placed on an agar plate inoculated with bacteria. The MIC is determined by the point where the elliptical zone of inhibition intersects the strip, indicating the lowest concentration of the antibiotic that prevents visible bacterial growth. This method is a form of antibiotic sensitivity testing.
